data.text: Contents

1.1. The Trust shall, as far as is reasonably practical, endeavour to ensure that staff achieve and maintain a high standard of performance in their work. It is important that appropriate standards are clearly established, performance is monitored and staff are given training and support to meet these standards.

1.2. The Trust acknowledges that poor performance, which is genuinely found to be related to the member of staff's capability, is not of the member of staff's own making will make attempts to achieve an agreeable solution. Failing which, dismissal could still be the conclusion. This is quite different to the Trust's Disciplinary Procedure which requires the member of staff's to conform to the expectations of the employer.
2.1. This policy covers all staff who are employed by the Trust.
2.2. For Medical and Dental staff, this policy should be ready in conjunction with the Department of Health's Maintaining High Professional Standards document.

2.3. The Trust is committed to providing high quality care through the effective management and development of its staff to ensure that they are, and remain capable of performing the duties for which they have been employed.

2.4. The following is intended to provide a framework to assist managers and staff in dealing with situations where the capability of a member of staff to perform their duties satisfactorily is called into question. Reasons for this may include poor job performance, lack of support or supervision or lack of understanding as to what is expected of them.

2.5. The emphasis of this framework is to promote and encourage improvement wherever possible by identifying problems at an early stage and exploring ways to address them. It is however recognised that there will be circumstances where it becomes necessary to consider the discontinuation of a member of staff's contract due to lack of capability.

2.6. The process will be exercised objectively, fairly, openly with common sense and with regard to the Trust's commitment to equality of opportunity. The procedure does not necessarily form part of a member of staff's contract of employment but is
a statement of the Trust's current practice and may be formally reviewed from time to time.

2.7. It should be recognised that there will be occasions when it will be necessary, because of the serious consequences of the poor performance, for the Trust's Disciplinary Procedure to be invoked which could result in a disciplinary sanction up to and including summary dismissal.

table_items.text: Refers to an individual's ability to perform the work expected of them to the required standards of the Trust.

Managing the performance of staff is a continuous supportive improvement process. Performance management occurs when a member of staff's performance falls below the standards required in order to fulfil the duties of the role.

The gap between what should be done and the reality of what is being done. There is a difference between what a member of staff might feel they need to do and what the Trust needs the member of staff to do. During the process, measures are agreed to address the gap in performance.

data.text: 4.1. The Chief Executive is responsible for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
4.2. Line managers are responsible for:
Setting, communicating and maintaining the standards of performance and behaviour expected of their staff;
Providing constructive feedback to staff on their performance, praising good performance and identifying where performance is below required standards;
Ensuring that staff receive proper induction, training and are aware of the specific requirements of their job;

Reviewing the performance of all managed staff effectively, identifying areas for improvement and agreeing a plan for how this improvement can be achieved. This will normally be managed through the appraisal process;

Identifying where performance is not satisfactory at the earliest possible opportunity and take action; seeking advice from Employee Relations and information from other appropriate sources where required;
Trying to resolve minor issues around performance through normal day to day management processes;
Making sure they are familiar with the Performance Improvement (Capability) Policy and Procedure and that all steps of the procedure are fully documented
Implementing any actions/recommendations arising from the process and keeping the member of staff informed of progress;
Keeping written records as appropriate ensuring confidentiality;
Applying the procedure consistently and in a way that is sensitive to issues of equality and diversity;
Ensuring timescales are adhered to and follow up meetings are held in a timely manner.
4.3. All staff are responsible for:
Carrying out their job to the standard that is expected of them and required for the role and grade;
Understanding the impact of their job performance on colleagues, patients/service users and stakeholders including the Trust generally and the healthcare community;
Clarifying expectations, tasks, objectives and behaviours with their line manager if they are unclear about them;
Engaging fully in their appraisal, the setting of their objectives and the assessment and monitoring of their performance;
Bringing all relevant issues which may affect their work and performance to the attention of their line manager at the earliest possible opportunity;
Co-operating with their manager to help improve any aspects of their work and performance which are considered to be unsatisfactory;
Attending meetings to discuss any aspects of their performance which are considered unsatisfactory as requested to do so;
Familiarising themselves with this procedure and the Trust's approach to performance management and capability matters;
Behaving professionally at all times during the capability process;
Maintaining the confidentiality of the process and not discussing the issues with anyone at the Trust other than their manager, their chosen companion or
Employee Relations;
Refraining from submitting inappropriate grievances, as the opportunity to express personal/individual views will be afforded during the process;
Seeking support from appropriate sources e.g. Occupational Health if required;
Participating fully in the process in order to ensure that a full and accurate process takes place and all the facts can be considered;
Remaining competent – keep up to date with the skills required to do the job;
Performing to their best ability.
4.5. The Employee Relations team is responsible for:

Providing specialist knowledge and advice of procedural issues, relevant policies and employment law matters to ensure fairness and consistency in approach, and includes the provision of confidential advice and assistance to managers on capability and performance management matters;
Attending formal meetings of the Performance Improvement Process Supporting the delivery of this policy and monitor its implementation.
4.5.  Representation
Staff have a right to be accompanied by a trade union representative or work place colleague at each formal stage of the procedure.

5.1. Standards of performance and objectives provide a means of measuring what is acceptable in terms of patient safety, quality, quantity, time or cost. They should be measurable, realistic and achievable and must be understood by all Trust staff.
5.2. When identifying areas of performance requiring improvement, managers must consider whether any shortfall in performance may be due to:
Unreasonable expectations or lack of explanation concerning the job;
A lack of understanding, or poor or inadequate supervision;
A lack of adequate training or qualification;
Lack of co-operation from other staff, or harassment/bullying;
Unreasonable levels of work;
Changes in the work environment that may impact adversely on the staff;

Any health or personal issues that may be impacting on work. If there are underlying personal or health issues, the member of staff may not feel comfortable explaining this to their manager and may self-refer to Occupational Health, the report from which they may submit in mitigation;
Systems and/or procedures which do not support what the member of staff is expected to achieve, or which are hard to understand or apply correctly.

5.3. Managers should identify as early as possible when performance fails to meet the required  standard, discuss  the  matter informally  with  the  member  of  staff  and determine how this may be addressed. Poor performance may not always be the fault of the member of staff and the Trust has an obligation to ensure that all the necessary support and guidance is available to staff to achieve good performance.
5.4. The issues must be addressed as soon as concerns arise, rather than wait for any review date that may be in the diary as part of the appraisal and development processes
5.5. Poor performance of one member of a team can affect the service provided by the ward/department and have an adverse effect on the morale and output of the remainder of the team.
5.6. Where performance concerns arise that appear to be due to lack of ability or skill, this must be evidenced. This could include:
 Work examples of where performance is not reaching the required standard;
 Evidence from complaints;
 Details of training undertaken;
 Actions and information provided as part of the induction procedures;
 Appraisal documentation and any Personal Development Plans agreed;
 Any action plans, objectives or standards set;
Records of informal and formal meetings, managers evidence of continued support.
5.7. If performance does not improve as a result of informal discussions the formal stages of the procedure should be followed.

6.1.  Where a member of staff's performance is being managed under the formal stage of the Performance Improvement (Capability) Procedure, pay steps under the Agenda for Change National Terms and Conditions of Service will not apply. Where performance improves to the required standard, the member of staff will become eligible to receive their Pay Step at the next Pay Step date. Back-dating of pay progression will not apply.

7.1. A manager and a member of staff may discuss and explore the possibility of redeployment to a more suitable, alternative role, at any time within the process. There is however no obligation to create a post specifically to accommodate the member of staff.
7.2. In all cases, redeployment to alternative employment must be by mutual agreement, with the member of staff's consent and in accordance with the Trust's Redeployment Policy and Procedure.
7.3. Redeployment may be at a different band, and if so the member of staff will assume the terms and conditions of the new post without protection of pay.
Informal Stage of the Procedure Initial Meeting (Stage 1)
8.1. Once performance issues have been identified, a meeting should be arranged between the manager and member of staff to discuss the issues.

8.2. It should be explained how the member of staff is not meeting the expected and required standards of performance. The member of staff should be allowed to respond to the concerns and provide any reasons why performance may not be at the required standard, for example:
Changes in the working environment that may be impacting adversely on the member of staff;
Health or personal issues that may be impacting on work performance;
Other problems or issues that may be contributing to poor performance;
Insufficient support and training.
8.3. Discussion will need to take place to determine whether any additional training or support is required and how this may be provided.

8.4. There should be agreement to the timeframe for these improvements. The time should be agreed between the member of staff and manager and should be sufficient to allow the member of staff to be able to achieve the improvements required and attend or undertake any reasonable training or development intervention that has been agreed as reasonable in the circumstances.
8.5. This will include in some cases, an expectation of an immediate improvement.

8.6. There will need to be discussion to ensure the member of staff is aware of what the consequences are of failing to improve performance, i.e. progressing the matter to the formal stage of this policy (stage 2).
8.7. There should be a written record of the meeting. This should detail:
 What the concerns are;
 What the required standards/expectations are;
 What support mechanisms are in place;
A date for review or deadline for completion of the objectives.

8.8. This record should be made on the Performance Improvement Action Plan (Appendix 2), a copy of which must be provided to the member of staff. Both copies must be signed by both the manager and the member of staff.
The Review Meeting
8.9. At the review meeting, performance should be discussed against the Performance Improvement Action Plan.

8.10. If all improvements have been achieved, the manager should write to the member of staff to confirm this. Manager will acknowledge and welcome the success of achieving the performance standards; and include the expectation of maintaining the required level of performance.

8.11. Where an improvement has not been made, the level of performance is still below the standard required, and an extension to the timeframes is not considered appropriate, the manager must advise the member of staff that a meeting will now be arranged under the formal stages of the policy (stage 2).
Formal Stages of the Procedure Stage 2
8.12. Should the member of staff show insufficient or no improvement after completion of the Informal stage, the member of staff will be invited in writing
to a formal meeting giving the full reasons for the meeting with at least calendar days' notice.

8.13. The line manager will chair the meeting and the member of staff has the right to be accompanied by a work colleague or trade union representative. The aims of this meeting and stage of the procedure will be as section 8 of the procedure above.
8.14. A Performance Improvement Action Plan (Appendix 2) should be completed and given to the member of staff.
Review period must be set of at least 4 weeks;
If improvements are met and required standards are achieved, then further review period of 4 weeks will be set to ensure standards are sustained. If no improvement, the member of staff moves to stage
Stage 3

8.15. At the end of the review period where no or little improvement has been made, a further formal meeting will be held to review the progress made in performance. The review period may be brought forward should performance issues become problematic. In either event, the member of staff will be invited to the meeting in writing giving the full reasons for it and reiterating that they have the right to be accompanied by a work colleague or trade union representative. At this time:
If the required improvement has been made, the member of staff will be informed of this and encouraged to maintain the improvement.
If some improvement has been made but the standard has not yet been met, the review period may be extended.
If the required improvement has not been delivered the member of staff will be advised of this and the need to attain the improvement as a failure to do so may result in dismissal at the next stage.
A separate Performance Improvement Action Plan (Appendix 2) should be completed and given to the member of staff.
The gravity of not making the required improvements and that a consequence of not doing so could result in dismissal will also be confirmed to the member of staff in writing by the Manger.
The outcome of this meeting will be confirmed in writing.
Stage 4 – Formal Hearing

8.16. If there has been no discernible or sustained improvement by the end of the third stage, then a formal hearing will be convened. The hearing will consist of a panel, chaired by a Manager whose status is the next level of seniority to the Line Manager, an Employee Relations team member and possibility a third panel
member. Where professional advice may need to be sought (e.g. nursing), the third panel member will take on the role of professional advisor to the panel.
8.17. The member of staff will be invited in writing giving the full reasons for the hearing and advising that they have the right to be accompanied by a work colleague or trade union representative.

8.18. The Management Case for the Hearing will consist of all the action plans that have been completed throughout the performance improvement process plus documented details of any review discussions that have taken place. The manager will present a summary of the activity that has taken place which has resulted with the establishment of the Hearing.
8.19. The Panel will consider whether the member of staff has failed to improve and meet the agreed standards and if so, if dismissal is an appropriate outcome.

8.20. Consideration will be given as to whether there are any suitable alternative vacancies that the member of staff would be competent to fill immediately and which may be available as an alternative to dismissal. Such an alternative could be immediate downgrading to a band below that of the member of staff's current role. If there are opportunities immediately available, the member of staff will be given the option of accepting such a vacancy (on the terms and conditions applicable to the alternative role); failing this they will be dismissed.

8.21. If such vacancies are available, the member of staff will be given full details of the vacancies, in writing, before being required to make a decision. That decision should be provided to the Panel within 48 hours of closure of the Hearing unless an alternative timescale is agreed (i.e. to accommodate weekends). The outcome will be confirmed to the member of staff in writing by the Chair of the Panel.
8.22. An alternative may be to identify a role in an alternative capacity elsewhere within the Trust. The Trust's formal redeployment process will be instigated with immediate effect.

8.23. A decision will be made by the Panel with regard to whether the member of staff continues in a limited capacity in their current role or whether an immediate temporary transfer is made to an alternative role whilst the redeployment process takes its course. Full details of the process will be confirmed to the member of staff in writing by the Chair of the Panel.
8.24. In either case, the member of staff will remain at Stage 3 of the Performance Improvement Procedure for a period of six months when the support and review

principles will continue. Should issues with performance remain a concern; the Panel will be reconvened. Should a Panel be reconvened for a second time its primary purpose will be to consider the dismissal of the member of staff.

8.25. In the absence of any appropriate alternative roles in any capacity at the time of the original (first) hearing, the member of staff will be told that the Trust has no alternative but to dismiss on the grounds of ‘capability'. The outcome will be confirmed to the member of staff in writing by the Chair of the Panel.
9.1.  Staff have the right to appeal against any formal decision appertaining to their employment and should do so in accordance with the Trust's Appeals Policy and Procedure.
10.1.  This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team.
